image.altText: A woman in a dressing gown sits on a hospital chair.

items.synopsis: A cancer patient at Royal Hobart Hospital says she got a letter with her dinner asking patients to consider leaving to help ease demand for beds.

title.children: Hospital patient gets letter with her dinner asking her to consider leaving to help free up beds

image.altText: An older man peers out his window. His chocolate brown cavoodle is on his lap and looks directly at the camera

items.synopsis: A Tasmanian man who was ramped for more than six hours says the state's hospitals are "broken", as unions claim it's the worst they've seen.

title.children: 'People are going to die': David needed to go to hospital quickly and ended up ramped in emergency for hours

image.altText: Lowe is wearing a blue suit, looking straight into camera, sitting at a desk.

items.synopsis: RBA governor Philip Lowe says we could manage inflation better, and floated ideas on how to do that, while addressing "vitriol" directed his way, in final speech.

title.children: RBA governor Philip Lowe warns about future inflation, criticises 'personal attacks', in final speech

image.altText: A young man with a beard.

items.synopsis: A major police operation is underway in Kellerberrin, with people being asked to stay indoors after a person was shot dead at a manufacturing plant.

title.children: Emergency helicopter dispatched, police to speak on active shooter after fatal silo shooting

image.altText: The website for eHarmony, which has a picture of a smiling blonde, white woman

items.synopsis: eHarmony is hit with a lawsuit by the consumer watchdog, alleging the dating site breached Australian consumer law by making misleading statements about the pricing, renewal and cancellation of its memberships.

title.children: eHarmony sued over alleged 'subscription trap' and other 'misleading' statements

image.altText: a baby maugean skate in front of a light, looks translucent and glows red

items.synopsis: The maugean skate, a species of ray, is only found in one waterway and it is thought there are fewer than 1,000 left.

title.children: It may not have the friendliest face, but $2.1m has just been spent to save it

image.altText: A whitish-blue iceberg floating in grey water.

items.synopsis: Funding and operational issues at the Australian Antarctic Division are having a "catastrophic" impact on critical research and damaging the organisation's international reputation, a Senate inquiry is told.

title.children: 'Removing the canary from the coal mine': Scientists alarmed over Antarctic research funding issues

image.altText: A man wearing a black cap with a beard speaks into a microphone.

items.synopsis: Outgoing RBA governor Philip Lowe has delivered his final public speech before handing over to Michele Bullock next week, while Mike Cannon-Brookes has officially taken over the divisive Sun Cable project in the NT. Follow live.

title.children: Mike Cannon-Brookes takes over Sun Cable, Lowe reflects on time as RBA governor before taking flight, ASX down

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Business reporter Emilia Terzon here! One of Australia's richest men has officially taken over the reigns at the divisive solar export project Sun Cable. You might remember that I travelled to the tiny town of Elliott (population just 287!) earlier this year to speak to locals there about the split between Sun Cable's two early backers, Mike Cannon-Brookes and Andrew Forrest. Elliott had been earmarked as the closest town to the site of the export project's massive solar farm. But locals there were getting fed up with project delays and Sun Cable's voluntary administration, that came after a split between the two billionaires over its vision to export solar to Singapore. I still remember one local's message to MCB and Forrest: "Get your act together". As of today, MCB formally controls Sun Cable through his venture Grok, with local partners including Quinbrook. And MCB reckons it is still very much possible to generate mass amounts of solar in central Australia, and send it through to Darwin and then onto Singapore via a sub-sea cable. "I acknowledge some people might think it's too ambitious, we don't believe it is," MCB told journalists in a briefing this afternoon. "Frankly, the technology exists to make this happen. "The next commodities boom in this country will not be founded on coal. It will be founded on the generation and export of our renewable energy. "Sun Cable is a world changing project and will be at the heart of Australia's drive to become a renewable energy superpower. " However, a final investment decision still hasn't been made. MCB says it'll come after talks with Singapore. He also confirmed that while the project will still very much continue to be based on sun, that it may also locally encorporate wind power. And as for his message to Elliott? He didn't confirm if it is still the chosen site of Sun Cable's solar farm when asked by ABC News, but did say he though the town's frustration was "totally understandable". "I wouldn't have wished this to be the path of the company and the project it has to take. I can understand the confusion and uncertainty." "I'm hopeful that we're not just exiting from that process, right? We are relaunching the project with new vim and vigor and commitment."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Mike Cannon-Brookes formally takes over Sun Cable

children.content: Business reporter Emilia Terzon here!
One of Australia's richest men has officially taken over the reigns at the divisive solar export project Sun Cable.

You might remember that I travelled to the tiny town of Elliott (population just 287!) earlier this year to speak to locals there about the split between Sun Cable's two early backers, Mike Cannon-Brookes and Andrew Forrest.
Elliott had been earmarked as the closest town to the site of the export project's massive solar farm.
But locals there were getting fed up with project delays and Sun Cable's voluntary administration, that came after a split between the two billionaires over its vision to export solar to Singapore.
I still remember
one local's message to
MCB and Forrest: "Get your act together".
As of today, MCB

formally controls Sun Cable through his venture Grok, with local partners including Quinbrook. And MCB reckons it is still very much possible to generate mass amounts of solar in central Australia, and send it through to Darwin and then onto Singapore via a sub-sea cable.
"I acknowledge some people might think it's too ambitious, we don't believe it is," MCB told journalists in a briefing this afternoon.
"Frankly, the technology exists to make this happen.
"The next commodities boom in this country will not be founded on coal. It will be founded on the generation and export of our renewable energy.
"Sun Cable is a world changing project and will be at the heart of Australia's drive to become a renewable energy superpower. "

However, a final investment decision still hasn't been made. MCB says it'll come after talks with Singapore. He also confirmed that while the project will still very much continue to be based on sun, that it may also locally encorporate wind power.
And as for his message to Elliott?
He didn't confirm if it is still the chosen site of Sun Cable's solar farm when asked by ABC News, but did say he though the town's frustration was "totally understandable".
"I wouldn't have wished this to be the path of the company and the project it has to take. I can understand the confusion and uncertainty."
"I'm hopeful that we're not just exiting from that process, right? We are relaunching the project with new vim and vigor and commitment."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: We know what some of you our dear readers thought of outgoing RBA Governor Philip Lowe's speech, so here are some thoughts from AMP chief economist Shane Oliver. He spoke to colleague Emily Stewart for her story on The Business tonight. On Mr Lowe's comments on better co-operation with government he said: "The importance, I think of a greater alignment between monetary policy and fiscal policy, I think is very insightful, we do rely very heavily on monetary policy, high interest rates to control inflation. But as he [Mr Lowe] points out, that can have a very unequal impact on people through society, obviously, particularly impacting those with with very high debt levels and obviously facing the impact of high mortgage rates." When it comes to calling out productivity : "I think he's also right to continue to point out the importance of boosting productivity. If we don't do that, if we don't build a consensus, as he says, to do that, then we will see our living standard suffer." And on Mr Lowe's comments about the media Dr Oliver said this: "I think he also rightly pointed out that the media has a role to play in this as well, and he has been somewhat misinterpreted on several occasions in recent times, which has made the setting of monetary policy at least the communication of monetary policy, but more complicated than it otherwise needed to be." Dr Oliver also noted the tarnish that will forever be Mr Lowe's legacy: "I think there's no doubt that Governor Lowe's legacy has been marred to some degree by the interest rate guidance in 2021, where he said that based on their current expectations, they didn't expect to raise interest rates until 2024. And of course, they had to start doing rate hikes through last year and of course, that threw many people ou t and got into the housing market. But by the same token, his heart was in the right place at the time, he was very fearful that the recovery in the economy would be very slow and consequently, unemployment would stay very high. So he was trying to provide confidence. It's always hard to know for sure, but I suspect that it did influence many people, otherwise, he wouldn't have made that guidance in the first place. He was he was hoping to encourage people to go out there and borrow and invest in housing and help the recovery in the economy. So I think there's no doubt that it had some impact people." You can see Emily's story on The Business tonight and on the ABC News YouTube channel later too.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: AMP chief economist Shane Oliver weighs in on Mr Lowe's final speech

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Time for a quick markets check - and remember about midday when I said there were only three companies in the top 200 that weren't losing value? Well there are more now. Leading the pack is lithium miner Liontown (see my earlier post for more on that). It's a bit of a mixed bag among the top 10. There are some mining, medical, energy and financial stocks in there. Here's the state of play: BHP continues to be drag today as it trades ex-dividend. It's down more than five per cent, but it's not the worst performer this afternoon. That trophy goes to Super Retail Group. All sectors are in the red today.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: The ASX extends losses, but there are a few bright spots

image.altText: Relaxed anonymous male teenager texting on mobile phone. His face is obscured by his hands and mobile in front of him.

items.synopsis: Recently emojis have landed some people in legal trouble in courts around the world. So what constitutes crossing the line?

title.children: Don't underestimate the legal implications of a thumbs-up emoji — it cost a Canadian man $90,000

image.altText: Bruce Bonyhady wearing a suit and tie and smiling.

items.synopsis: Federal, state and local governments should strike a new funding agreement to build “foundational supports” for people with disabilities in settings like schools and family centres to reduce the strain on the NDIS, according to the chair of an independent review of the scheme.

title.children: The keys areas the NDIS review chair is looking to reform

image.altText: Brownstones in Brooklyn, New York

items.synopsis: New York is making big changes to its short-term rental rules, but it's not the only major city to do so.

title.children: New York is cracking down on Airbnbs. Here's how The Big Apple and other cities are tackling short-term rentals

image.altText: Sombre young woman stands on the street in front of a large colourful heart sculpture, long brown hair, fuchsia coloured dress.

items.synopsis: Sereena Zanuso survived a record-breaking flood last year but 18 months on, she's still feeling eco-anxiety. She's one of thousands of young Australians who feel the same way.

title.children: More than half of young people are experiencing eco-anxiety. Here's why

image.altText: A globe centred on Australia showing rainfall anomaly patterns, mostly red to indicate dryness. A date indicates August 2023

items.synopsis: It’s the phenomenon behind some of Australia’s hottest, driest years, and climate change could be making it more extreme. Here’s why that doesn’t guarantee catastrophe this year — or in the future.

title.children: An El Niño could be declared as early as next week: This is what it looks like when it forms

image.altText: Anthony Albanese and Xi Jinping smiling and shaking hands

items.synopsis: The prime minister says he will travel to China to mark the 50th anniversary of former PM Gough Whitlam's historic visit to the country, also becoming the first Australian leader to go to China since 2016.

title.children: Albanese confirms China trip for later this year

image.altText: Close up of Alan Joyce

items.synopsis: Alan Joyce reportedly jets off with a substantial amount of cash and Qantas shares in his portfolio — but valid questions are being asked about whether he is entitled to all of it.

title.children: Qantas' board is under enormous pressure to scrap Alan Joyce's final payout. Could they actually do it?

image.altText: A woman in a yellow jacket, a woman in a navy jacket sit on a green bench seat while a man stands and shouts

items.synopsis: The heated discussion over why Qatar Airways' bid to increase flights to Australia was rejected has left the government juggling excess political baggage, writes Brett Worthington.

title.children: 'C'mon, guys, you know people are watching': When all hell broke loose in Question Time, an independent stood up

image.altText: Catherine King stands at lecturn in front of airport signage

items.synopsis: Catherine King says the 2020 incident was one factor in her decision to reject Qatar's application to increase its flights to major Australian airports, but that no single issue swayed her one way or the other.

title.children: 'Absolute nonsense': Transport minister rejects claims Qatar flights would make big difference to ticket prices

image.altText: An ambulance and a crashed car surrounded by emergency services

items.synopsis: A court hears the 33-year-old man was travelling at least 130 kilometres per hour in the lead-up to the crash which killed two children.

title.children: Sydney man weeps in court after being denied bail over crash that killed two young boys

image.altText: Two trailers with a stack of mattresses on the back

items.synopsis: WA's largest regional city is facing an expensive clean up bill for 15,000 discarded mattresses after environmental regulators deemed them a serious fire risk.

title.children: Why 15,000 old mattresses are proving to be a multimillion-dollar headache

image.altText: A woman crouching looking up at a furry animal and patting it as its held by another person.

items.synopsis: The environment minister hopes to avoid more species becoming extinct due to feral cats, as a draft plan to contain the animals is released for consultation.

title.children: Federal government declares 'war' on feral cats

image.altText: A group of men wearing suits

items.synopsis: Police allege the 61-year-old concealed a serious indictable offence after the incident on Friday night, where two people were killed in Sydney's south-west.

title.children: Father of alleged hit-and-run driver charged with hindering investigation into fatal Sydney crash

image.altText: Missing man Keith, who went missing near Portland in Victoria, wearing a green shirt and in front of a white background

items.synopsis: Keith Lees, 70, has been missing since June after he was visited by police about the case.

title.children: Family appeal to Keith Lees to hand himself in over Meaghan Louise Rose murder investigation

image.altText: A man wearing a blue jumper and a baseball cap

items.synopsis: Police are investigating if the remains are those of Robert Atkins, who was reported missing in early 2021.

title.children: Human remains found at rural SA property, police say

image.altText: three men at sea.

items.synopsis: Australian Border Force officers have greeted three sailors who had to be rescued from a sinking catamaran in the Coral Sea.

title.children: Rescued sailors make it back to port after inflatable boat savaged by sharks

image.altText: a small shark out of water

items.synopsis: Three sailors attempting a round-the-world voyage have been rescued after their boat was attacked off the coast of Cairns and began to sink. It's suspected their craft was set upon by cookiecutter sharks.

title.children: How a 40-centimetre shark brought a catamaran's round-the-world voyage to a halt

image.altText: A man in a dark corner putting his hands on a red brick wall and his feet on the opposite white wall floating above ground

items.synopsis: Police are flooding a search zone of increasingly worried residents in Philadelphia after revealing a killer escaped prison by scaling a wall and going undetected for an hour.

title.children: Murderer 'crab-walked' himself out of US prison, authorities reveal as seven-day manhunt drags on

image.altText: A sinkhole in a street.

items.synopsis: A large sinkhole in the middle of an Adelaide street is believed to have been caused by a break in the sewer main, causing a malodorous mess to flood into surrounding properties.

title.children: Sinkhole stink as sewage floods properties in suburban Adelaide street

image.altText: A smiling young man in a racing driver's jumpsuit holds a trophy and raises his finger in triumph.

items.synopsis: Formula 500 driver Luke Nardini has been charged with manslaughter following a crash that occurred while he was allegedly driving on the wrong side of a US highway. His mother says her son is deeply saddened by the "terrible" incident.

title.children: Community devastated as Australian racing driver charged over deadly crash in California

image.altText: Zombie fish in researchers hands

items.synopsis: Native southern purple-spotted gudgeon fish — thought to have been extinct for two decades — have been released into a Victorian wetland.

title.children: 'Zombie' fish once thought extinct released into wild

image.altText: Two police officers take a selfie photo with a smiling man and woman next to the ocean at sunset.

items.synopsis: After hearing a scream, Eric Krins and Maree Pearson did not hesitate to rush to the aid of the 67-year-old woman at a remote WA beach.

title.children: Byron Bay couple become holiday heroes with daring rescue of Ningaloo snorkeller 80m from shore

image.altText: A submarine at the surface with morning sun on its right flank, the ocean stretches behind it

items.synopsis: As some Republicans raise concerns about the deal to supply American subs to Australia, a US Senate committee hears China's recent behaviour means "time is of the essence" in the trilateral AUKUS pact.

title.children: 'This is a critical moment': China's behaviour towards Australia makes AUKUS more urgent, US senator warns

image.altText: Kourtney Kardashian Barker's foetal pregnancy Instagram post

items.synopsis: The reality television personality says she walked out of hospital 'with my baby boy in my tummy' and a new understanding for mothers who had dealt with difficult pregnancies.

title.children: Kourtney Kardashian Barker says she has new respect for mothers after 'urgent fetal surgery'

image.altText: the front of a house and carport, with the ocean seen behind it

items.synopsis: The rise of short-term holiday rentals like Airbnb and Stayz have changed the way we travel, but they've also faced backlash over concerns they're driving rents up and exacerbating housing shortages in cities around the world.

title.children: Short-term rentals are often blamed for exacerbating the housing crisis. Now the regulation is catching up

image.altText: Natalie Sinclair sitting at a table, reaching towards bottles of Hysone and Hydrocortisone.

items.synopsis: The drug Natalie Sinclair takes to keep her alive is among hundreds of medications that have been in short supply in Australia, but advocates fear stockholding laws for suppliers are having little impact on the ground.

title.children: More than 400 medicines are in 'short supply' in Australia. Advocates are calling for change

image.altText: Composite photo of The Rolling Stones and Sydney Sweeney

items.synopsis: Fans haven't heard new music from the veteran rockers since 2005's A Bigger Bang.

title.children: Rolling Stones announce first album of new music in 18 years, bring Sydney Sweeney along for the ride
